div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
BRITISH FOREIGN POLICY
div.p: ITS CARDINAL Points
SPEECH by SIR E. Grey.
London, October 20.

Sir Edward Grey, speaking in the City, said that no Liberal Government would change any of the three cardinal points of the present foreign policy, namely, the friendship with America, the alliance with Japan, and the agreement with France. It is desirable, how- ever, to re-establish the position of Russia in the councils of Europe. Any improvement in Anglo-Gorman relations must be conditional on fair or good Franco-German relations. The alliance with Japan is defensive, and it is not intended that it should be used by any party- in England for a policy of expansion on the Indian frontier. (Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY
div.p: have been requested to state that owing to the lateness of tho season tbe Chryoauthomum Show has boon postponed to the 4th and 5th November. Stray Dogs- Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Ain Chams district of Cairo during the night of Sunday, and in the Khalifa district during the night of Monday, will he poisoned by the police. Supreme Consular Court— Advice has been received at tho British Consulate, Cairo, that the Judge of H.B.M.’s Supreme Consular Court in tho Ottoman Dominions will visit Egypt about tho middle of November. Alexandria Rowing Club.—Tho club promises a capital program for this after- noon, when tho now boat shed will be declared upon. Swimming and boat races, a blind-fold race, a tug-of-war. and a water tournament will be among the events of the afternoon. Coal Imports.—During the period from January 1 to October 19. 866,387 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent -131,589, Newcastle 206,586, Scotland 105.485, York- shire 61,225, and other places 32,509 tons During the same period of last you 851,601 tons wore received. Reward of Zeal. - We hear that H.H the Khedive has been graciously pleased to promote to tho rank of Boy the Omdeh of Toukh El Caramons, thanks to whose energy the recently discovered Ptolemaic treasure was preserved almost intact till tho arrival of tho inspector! of tho Antiquities Service'. Scaffold Accident —A native boy, about „ 12 years of age, working on some buildings under construction in Ramleh boulevard, fell off a scaffolding this morning, fracturing his skull. He was brought by a shawish for first aid to Mugnier's pharmacy, on the opposite side of the road, and was then sent to hospital.

Memorial to Col. Rhodes.—The Duke of Abercorn, the Earl of Cromer, Field-Marshal Sir George White, Major-General Frank S. Russell, and Lord Harris have constituted themselves a committee for tho purpose of collecting funds to raise a memorial to Colonel Frank Rhode". Subscriptions are limited to a , maximum of three guineas. Tho form which it , is proposed the memorial shall take will be , communicated in due course to the subscribers. Meantime subscriptions can be sent to Lord Harris, Belmont, Faversham. Carlton Hotel.—Some time ago we announced that Mr. Aquilina intended enlarging his Carlton Hotel at Bulkeley, and we now learn that the work will soon be completed. There will be added 20 more bedrooms, a dining- room 18 metres long by 9 wide, a billiard- room of the same size, a bar, and a large verandah overlooking the fashionable pro- menade. These improvements will no doubt 1 greatly enhance the-popularity of this hotel, 1 and Mr. Aquilina will bo enabled to accom- modate a considerable number of his clients and friends, many of whom are constantly being turned away,owing to the limited number , of rooms. The Carlton Hotel is open all the year round and it is at most times “full up " Amongst tho«e staying there at present are Mr. and Mrs. Trevithick, Mr. B. Verschoyle, Mr. James B. Clarke, M. Bayonmi Bey, Mme and Mile Strafti, Mr. and Mrs. Bigi-ivi, Mr. L. Edgar, Mr. H. Ward-Boys, Dr. Schemed, Mr. J. W. Williams, Mr. B. Gorra, Mr. and - Mrs. H. R. Scott.

div.head: MANSOURAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW
div.p: INAUGURATED BY KHBDIVB.

The Khedivial train reached Mansourah at 11.45 am. yesterday and H.H. the Khedive and the Ministers who accompanied him found the station decorated in honor of his arrival. H.H. Prince. Hussein Pasha Kamel, Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun. The Mondirs of Dakah- lioh and the other Delta provinces with the lading members of the Khedivial Agrionlt ral Society and the principal functionaries and notables of the province, met the Khedive on Irsairva!. His Highness then proceeded to for prayer, after- wards presiding at the banquet of 100 covers Gored by the Municipal Commission of the town, and after the banquet, formally opened the agricultural show.

The show which was held on the property of the Russian Consul 'M. Greiss was a great success, the arrangements being thoroughly good and the exhibits admirable. The show of horses and mules-over 600 in number— was one of tho beat ever soon in Egypt, the mares being particularly admired. Tho camels went also well worth seeing, the sheep and ' goats fair, the entries in tho last two classes being rather small.

Though small the exhibits of fruit, vege tables, butter, and choose were of excellent quality, and the poultry and pigeons shown were mostly of good breeds. The cotton exhibits wore numerous and surprisingly good, and greet interest was taken in the hand worked lioms and the beautiful silk and cotton fabrics which they turned out. As for the arrangements, they were very good. The judges, though hard worked, had given every award bofore the opening of the show, the arrangement of tho tents contain- ing the exhibits was excellent, and tho mar- quee where the banquet in honor of H. H. ths Khedives visit was held, was luxuriously decorated, Khedive's seat being flanked and overhung by,living orange trees. That numerous victors, European and native, from Cairo and the provinces were there, gees without saying. Major Watson, Major Lsatrange Jobnstono, Mr. P. W. Machell and quite a number of British officials were present, all much interested in the show, and all the notables of the province seemed to have gathered together for the occasion. The organizers of the exhibition deserve great credit for their, success, and the general impression felt by European editors was one of the most 'satisfaction. At the high quality of the exhibits and the evidence they afforded of the interesting prosperity of the Delta. The railway service gave the minimum of satisfacion to all concerned.

div.head: THE ROYAL TOUR
div.p: We are informed by tho British Agency that A T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales will not visit Cairo on their way to India. According to present arrangements, their Royal Highnesses will remain at Port Said for 24 hours, and than continue their voyage through the Canal
No official arrangements have been made for their recaption, and it will not be known until tho arrival of H.M.8. Renown whether they w.ll disembark at Port Said or spend the whole time on board.

div.head: LORD CROMER’S RETURN.
div.p: Our contemporary "Al Mokattam" publishes one verses of which we give the following rough translation. Tho last line makes a tarikh, a the numerical value of each of its Arabic a letters when added together making the date a 1323 A.H. (1°05 A.D.) Praise to Allah, the Lord has returned from his journey. In safety, as the sap returns to the trees. He has returned to watch over the people's affairs and as a reformer. Not to observe the crops and fruits of the land. So Egypt rejoices and makes tho tarikh The Lord has come, and justice grown familiar follows in his steps.

div.head: THE SUDAN BUDGET.
div.p: We are informed by a correspondent in the Sudan that tho Sudan Budget Estimates for he coming year provide for a deficit of little over LE 250,000 to be made up by Egypt. The steady decrease of tho Sudan deficit, which amounted to over LE. 370,000 in 1904, is a gratifying evidence of the- return of pros- perity that has followed tho Anglo-Egyptian , reconquest.

div.head: THE DUBLIN FUSILIERS.
div.p: A FAMOUS REGIMENT.

Passage from Malta to Egypt has bean provided in the transport Assaye, arriving at Alexandria on the 20th November next, for the undermentioned details of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers.—Majors A J. Chap- man and G. Downing; Captain A. Lovebank, wife, child, and nurse; Captain M. B. Lonsdale, wife, child, and nurse;Captains G.B J. Riccard and C. T. W. Grimshaw; Lieutonante T. H. C. Frankland, W. P. Stirling, J. C.’ Lamprey, A. H. Woodhouse and A. Broadhurst-Hill; 2nd- Lieutenants E. V. Knox, A. M. Johnson, C. B. R. Hoey, and A. W. Maloney ; Lt. and Qr. j Mr. L. Holloway, wife, and 3 children; Sgt- Maj. A. K Williams, wife, and 2 children ; Bandmaster Fawcett and wife; 29 sergeants;' 3 drummers; 19 corporals ; 413 privates ; women, and 17 children.

Some details concerning tho 1st Battalion of the Royal Dublin Families will no doubt; interest our readers. Tho battalion is one of the oldest regiments in the British Army, being originally raised for the protection of the East India Company's factories in Sor thorn ' India as early as 1644. Tho regiment was always composed of British soldiers, and has always had a large percentage of Irishmen in it In 1748, the detached companies protecting factories were formed into a regiment under command of the famous Stringer Laurence, with its headquarters at Madras, and was called the Madras European Regiment. From that date until the end of the 18th century it was constantly in active service, striving for England's supremacy in India—it bears on its colors the well-known honors of Arcot, Condoro, Wandewaab, Sholingur, Non- dydroogf.dicharry, etc.,—and bad in its ranis such famous men as Stringer Laurence, Robert C!i*$ ^Joseph Smith, Culliard, Hector Munro, John Malcolm, and many others who made history in India. In the 19th century the regiment served in Central India, tho first Burmese war, tho Burmah war of 1954, and in the groat Indian Mutiny of 1857, when it was the first of the British troops to come to the assistance of Bonaros and Allahabad under command of the ever-to be-remembered Neill. It then served in Havelooki's Field Force, which eventually forced its way into Lucknow on the 25th September au 1 relieved the Residency, after which it served under Sir James Ootram at the famous post of the Alumbagb, took part in the final relief of Luoknow under Sir C4in Campbell (Lord Clyde), and finally served in Hope Grant’s column, which eventually reconquered the whole of Oade. On returning to Madras, the Governor General of India caused the regiment to be received with full military honors in Calcutta and publicly thanked the regiment for its valuable services.

In 18S2 the regiment was transferred from the East India Company’s service to the Queen's army and was styled the l02nd Royal Madras fusiliers. In 1881, this title was changed under the territorial system to 1st Battalion loyal Dublin Fusiliers, and the old Bombay fusiliers, then called the 103rd Royal Bombay ‘asiliers, »ero made 2nd Battalion. The regi- root saw no other active service until the v oath African war, when both battalions ten sent out and served throughout the campaign, proving how well they deserved he proud regimental motto of 'Spectrum n agendo.

div.head: THE PISANI CASE.
div.p: Yesterday morning, Dr. Haywood visited the l Menshieh prison, Cairo, in order to make a medical examination of Pisani, the Maltese, who lately tried to murder his mistress and afterwards attempted to shoot himself, t The doctor came to the conclusion that it was ' quite possible that tho ballet still remained lodged in the head of the prisoner, and he therefore ordered his removal to the Deacon asses’ Hospital, where be operated on him later in the day. The ballet was found in the baok of the mans neck, dose to the junction of the skull and the vertebral column, but slightly to \ the left side of tho medial line. The position of the bullet gives rise to the suspicion that it was not a self-inflicted wound.

Pisaui’s victim is now to be examined. 1 If there is a favorable report of the woman’s condition from the doctors accused will in all probability be granted bail on his application i to-day. Meanwhile, he lies in hospital very ill, and though his condition is not considered serious we understand that there is a danger of erysipelas setting in and retarding his recovery considerably.

div.head: PRO CALABRIA.
div.p: KHBDIYIAL BENEFIT CONCERT.

An previously announced in our columns benefit concert will be given at the Kbedivial Opera House, Cairo, on Thursday next, for the relief of the victims of the recent Calabrian earthquakes. Io bringing this more prominently before the public, we cannot do better i than reproduce the circular issued by the committee which has been charged with this labour of love "Under the most distinguished patronage ot I his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, the Bari of Cromer, Q.C.B., their Excellencies the Con- sals General for Italy, 8pain and America, the General and officers of the British Army, and the Sirdar and officers of the Egyptian Army, a grand concert has been arranged by the I l Cairo Musical and Dramatic Society, to take I place in the Opera House, Cairo, on Thursday, 26th inst, at 9 p.m., in aid of the sufferers by the recent earthquakes in Calabria. The lol- lowing ladies and gentlemen have generously j given their services Madame Amster, Mrs. Douegan, Miss Delanoy, Mile Sohall and Miss | Congdon ; Major J. F. Donegan, Messrs. Mat- talon, Brown, Wood, Goets, Congdon, Peaoook, | Hayes and Valentino. By kind permission, the | band of the 1st King’s Royal Rifles will also j take part in the programm | "At this moment, when piteous ones for help in aid of the poor, wretched, and desolate, . iD that afflicted land, reach us from across the sea does it not behove us, one and all, to do what little we can to alleviate, cheer, and sos- tain those who are in such dire distress f Will I you not, of your kind charity, therefore, join ns ' in our endeavors to make this concert a great success 1 The committee, in making this appeal, feel confident that it will be heartily respond- ed to. Plan of theatre can be seen, seats book- ed, and all other particulars obtained at the offices of Messrs. Congdon & Co., opposite the British Head Quarters. Wo must also mention that the Stemway grand piano has kindly been lent for the occasion by 8ignor Vincent Gra- uato-Mezricapo. The following are the priots of admissionbaignoires, P.T. 800 ; 1st tier boies, P.T. 220 ; 2nd tier boxes, PT. 100 ; orchestra stalls, P.T. 25 ; stalls, P.T. 20,16 and 10 ; gallery, P.T. 5.”

div.head: MATTERS OF MOMENT. PITH OF THE PRESS COMMENT
AMERICAN INSURANCE SCAM
div.p: “Times”

The gigantic dealings of trusts and syndi- cates often exert a sufficiently unpleasant pres- sure on the ordinary American, but the be- setting evils in the financial life of his country are likely to be much more directly home to him by proceedings that shake faith in the integrity of the great insurance companies. In England, we are glad to think the management of insurance business regarded as what it really is—a trust the most responsible sacred kind. There can be no final security for the Ami policyholder until a similar standard is i tained in the Union.
ENGLAND AND THE CONTINENTAL PRESS.
“Standard."

Englishment are not likely to be disturbed in their minds by the tone which has suddenly been assumed towards this country by some ot the Gorman newspapers . It is perfectly well known to Prince Below that, throughout the Morocco France never asked, and Great Britain offered, help against the 'Fatherland. It was never belived, either in Paris or London that the dispute which ended in the fall of M. Delcasse would result in war. There need be no ambiguity or equivocation in the matter. The German publicists who are potting forward a different view of tho are either drawing upon their imagination or have been misled by their informs Which is the correct alternative it is business of ours to enquire.
"Daily News.”

For every reason we regret the publicity which has been given to these real or Ima- ginary intrigues. The disclosures in “Matin” have become pregnant with possible peril to the tranquillity of Europe. And it is high time that Lord Lanadowne should explain and defend this chapter in the diplomacy for which be and his colleagues are consti- tutionally responsible. There has been a i dency of late to place Lord Lansdowne u a pinnacle, but the country will have little reason to thank him if it be found t be has permitted this country to drift i entanglements directly involving a risk European war.
"Globe."

Recent episodes in our own political annuals may stop us from emphasizing too strong to our neighbors the evils of paper warfare Bat we would suggest in all seriousness and in all humility that the time has come bury the hatchet, before the relations between Berlin and Paris become still farther ex cerbeted. And we are entitled to make the suggestion both by the general terms of the Anglo-French agreement, and by the manner in which, a supposed undertaking by the country has been made the crucial point tha revelation a "Toa res agitur paries qua proximus ardet," and we cannot affect to regard with indifference the sight of ts neighboring nations lashing themslves into a state of mutual indignation over a hypo- thetical indiscretion on the part of an indi- vidual who, for the moment at any rate has disappeared from the public life of country.
"Westminister Gazette.”

Of course, if the half that the “Matin reported were true, we should bave to st that recent events, so far from leaving an ground for satisfiotion to the British an Prend) Governments, had convicted them both ota moat serions lose of head and nerve in a emergency in which evilness and discretion were the most necessary qualities. We do not say it, for we believe the denials which come from both parties to be sincere. Bat the inci- dent does most seriously warn us of the consequences which may follow i£ in our tel elation about the greatness and grandeur our new consistent foreign policy, we either forget the limits of British power or encourage our neighbors to entertain illusions on that subject.
"MANCHESTER GUARDIAN.”

It is an awfal reflection that our Government should have pot it in, anyone's power to ad- vertise our willingness under certain contin gencies to go to war with Germany. That these contingencies ever actually came is beside the question, in as much is as the question was, in fact decided by fall of M Delasse and the moderation' of the French Government, and not by anything that our own Government did or said later. We hesitate still to think that our Government can have been guilty of the folly attributed to it, in all its enormity.
“Petit Parisien”

We understand that we hare friends, hot we rejectcomplaoact solidarity which my develop into complicity in the disturbance peace. A highly-placed official has informed Berlin correspondent of the “Petit-Peris that the British Government has already given reassuring explanations to Germany, and probably furnish others. "So far as we concerned," said this official, “we attach little importance to this pretended revelations which everyone is now discussing.”
“Figaro”

Whatever M. Delcasse may think, the d’menti which he gives to the alleged reve- lations huions of the last few days was not superfluous. The silence of the former Minister for Pore Affairs termed to confirm the authenticity of these revelations. We are not the only ounce Who have been affected by this silence. M. Deloasse has read the English newspaper for some days past—only to mention Times”, “The Westminster Gazette”, The Daly News," "The Standard"—he will have Seen the disastrous effect which this divulge- tion of State secrete produced in the eyes of the people whose esteem we are anxious to regain as we are their valuable friendship.
"Temps.”

Apropos of the indiscretions committed which there is reason to regret, it is proper entry remark that out of the eleven Ministers pre- sent at the Cabinet Council it is impossible that one or two should not have confided to their political friends, journalists, or members never of Parliament what had occurred. The era of diplomatic, ministerial, and parliamentary. Secrecy has long come to a close. There is no reason for self-congratulation at this, but one Is obliged to note.
"RAPPEL"

The "Rappel" remarks that the German Press is only too glad to be able to cry that an attempt was made to fly at the throat of. Germany without warning her, but adds that Germany would do well to find ont how much truth there is in those pretended revelations.
“HUMANITE”

M. Jaurès in the "Humanite,” says that, given the present political situation in Europe, the moment is well chosen for a union between France and Great Britain with a view to bumbling Germany. Francs will never find a more favorable opportunity for warlike action, but she desires peace and is averse to adventures in which blind force would pre- dominate. She can give no more striking proof of this to. the world, and even to Germany, than the repudiation of the Delcassé policy, which was leading straight to war.
"Aurore.”

M. Gerault-Richard, in the "Aurore," ob- nerves that if the foreign Press reproaches M. Dalcassé with having increased the uneasiness of Europe the reason is that M. Delcassé per- haps failed to realize tho significance of La Fontains fable of the frog who wished to be ai big as an ox.
"Cologne Gazette.”

The "Cologne Gazette” asserts that the polioy of M. Delcassé very nearly plunged Europe into a terrible war, and for this reason it would like to know who it was that pro duced in M. Delcassé's mind the impression that he would have British support A broad hint is given that tho corrrect answer to this question can only be discovered in England or in France, and this answer would at all events be more interesting than the method which is at present preferred of simply denying the accuracy of the disclosures.
"Die Post" (Berlin).

"Die Post” says that explanations of an authoritative character must be given in the British Parliament, explanations which will create tho needful clearness. This is not a matter which can remain a secret of diplomacy. It has assumed far too wide dimensions for this.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Tho troopship Assaye is due to leave Southampton on tho 8th November on a relief run to the Mediterranean and India. At tho port of departure she will embark the 4th Battalion Riffle Brigade for Malta and various drafts of garrison artillery and infantry for the same station and for India. She will convey the balance Of the Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers from Malta To Alexandria, arriving at the latter port on the 20th. The 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigs will embark on the liner, after three years Service in Egypt and the Sudan, and proceed to Bombay, arriving there on the 1st Decem- ber. Tho battalion will proceed to Chanbattia Bengal, there to be stationed. It was last in India from 1867, including the Mutiny till 1867. In the interim it served with distinc- tio in the Ashanti War, 1872-73, the Susan Campaign, 1898, including the battle of Om- durman, and it shared in the defence of Ladysmith during the late South African War.

The 3rd Battalion Kings Royal Rifle Corps is due to learn Bermuda to-day en route for home per the S.S. Kensington. On arrival at Southampton about the 23rd inst. the battalion will proceed to Aldershot to be stationed.

Captain F. W. Foley, Royal Berkshire Kegi- ment, lately employed at the Royal Military College, Sandhurst, in command of a company of gentlemen cadets, has been posted to the 1st Battalion at Dablin on absorption and joined for duty on the 11th inst.

Quartermaster and Honorary Captain Arthur White from the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, Khartoum, has been appointed quartermaster of the Rifle Depot, Winchester. This officer enlisted in the ‘ Green Jackets” in 1881, and after close on 16 years' service in the ranks he got his commission in May, 1897. He was ill Sir Charles Warren's expedition to Bechnana- land, 1894, and was quartermaster of the 2nd Battalion of the Brigade in Kitchener's avenge Ing in march to Khartoum, including the battle of Omdurman (medal, and Khedive's medal with clasp)

Lieutenant Herbert N. Young, 1st Batta- lion, Royal laniskilling Fusiliers, has been selected for service with the West African Frontier Force, and joins a battalion of the Northern Nigeria Regiment Lieutenant Yonng was appointed to the inniskillings in Jane, 1901, and joined the 1st Battalion at the front and served ,without tilt the close of the "war (medal with three clasps).

Major L.H.R. Pope-Hennessy Oxfordshire Light Industy, the soound in command of the 3rd Battalion King’s. African Rifles, at Nai- robi, East Africa, has been making things uncomfortable for certain native chiefs, whose ways and manner of conducting public affairs were anything but correct. These potentate* raided the Masais and other tribesmen friendly to British rule, killed a few of them, and took away their cattle and goods. The gallant major with a small force of the EA R. gave these brutal chiefs a lesson in good behaviour, and in turn carried off 1,(0J head of cattle and 4,000 goats. A portion of the proceeds went to the unfortunate Masais by way of compensation.
Lieutenant L. S. Coke, Irish Guards, and Captain P. R. Anley, Notts and Derby Regiment, have been sec.

It has been decided to make provision for the establishing of "miniature cartridge ranges" at all Line Depots in lien of those known as "miniature ranges" for service cartridges. In the future the latter will come under the beading of "ranges thirty yards in extent" The Atlantic Fleet will come home for Christmas leave, as the facilities for shore going on the station are limited. It seems that Edhem Pasha, the Sultan’s champion soldier, is not dead after all, mere'y another man of the same name. It is a little tactless of a contemporary to say that it regrets the mistake.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES REPORT.
div.p: TEXT OF SECOND REPORT.
We give below the text of the second report of the experts appointed by Judge Took tore port on the situation of tho Sucreries Com pany-
Monsieur le Juge-Commis,
Les travaux complémentiires que nous ve- nons de faire pour ;’establishment du présent rapport, confirment entièrement les observa- tions et appréciations contenues dans notre rapport précédent.

Nous vous soumettons aujourd'hui, ainsi qao nous vous l’avions promis, les compte- détaillés de l'exploitation générale et ceux des profits et pertee de la 8ociété Générale des 8ooreries ot de la Raffinerie d'Bgypte, mais poor 6 exercices an. lien de 2, soit, depnis le 1er novembre 1899 jnsqn'an 31 août 1905. Vous y trouverez des chiffres in téreasants et vous pourrez faire des compa- raisons pins intéressantes encore, qui voua donneront nne idée bien nette du fonctionne- ment économiqne de oette Société.
Suit l'analyse des tableaux annexés an rapport:

Le dernier tableau établissant les prix mo- yens des snores produits et vendos depuis 1899 démontre que seulement pour l'exeroioe 1899-1900 les pnx de vente ont été'supé- rieurs aux prix de revient dans les usines, d’où le bénéfice dans l'exploitation propre- ment dite de Let 6.431 ; en 19oO-1901 le déficit eat de Lit. 37.378 ; on 1901-1902 de let. 119.686, e? si en 1902-1908 il n'est que de Lst. 2.886, oela provient d'un. boni de Let 94.998, trouvé dans les magasins des usines Daira Sanieb. De même en 1903- 1904 le déficit est ré luit h Lst. 7.017, grâce : I. à la Daira Sanieb qui oonsent à vendre ses sucres k raison de 31 Pt. 35 le cantar alors qne le prix le plus bas pour les achats faits dans le oourant du même exer- cioe est de 45 Pt. 45.

2.—Par suite des reports des dépenses sur l'exercice 1904-1905 soit: le*solde débiteur des ateliers de Minieb; la moitié des dé- penses occasionnées par les uaipes fermées Hrment ot Rodah ; les déficits des cultures. Noua reparlerons plus loin do ces reports. Noua voyons douo que/« usina travaillaient d perle, et que Ica déficits su maintenaient k des chiffre élevés que la arbitrages devaient combler chaque année, et en plus, fournir 1er sommes nécessaires pour solder les chargea sociales, frais généraux d'administration ot distribuer un dividende aux actionnaires. Dans oea eonditiors, noos estimons que le Conseil d'administration, avant do réaliser l’achat si important des usines- Daira Sanieb, devait montrer aux' actionnaires la situation vraie de son exploitation industrielle et lui indiquer clairement la provenance des bfnifica qu'on leur distribuait.

On peut vérifier en lisant le oompto rendu des réunions d'actionnaires qui ont eu lieu k Paris en oes derniers temps ot les avis donnés dans les journaux d'Europe par des gens ee croyant bien renseignés, que le publio était oonvainou qu'industriellement l'affaire en elle- même était excellente, alors qu’elle n'a donné, depuis 1900, que des pertes et aussi, qu'il ignore encore le danger résultant de la culture du coton qui tend de plus en plus à remplacer celle de la canne, ou tout au moins k la diminuer dans des proportions qui augmen- teront certainement les prix de revient du sucre fabriqué. Si voua pouviez avoir le moin- dre doute à oe sujet, Monsieur le Juge-Com- mis, noua vous prierions de consulter les cinq premiers tableaux, et vous pourrez voir que les naines qui produisent dans les meilleures conditions sont justement celles dont l'alimen- tation journalière est largement assurée et qui travaillent de grandes quantités de cannes, exemple : Cheikh-Fadl et Abou-Kourgas, cela en dehors de leurs rendements qui ne sont pas plus élevés, en général, que oeux des antres usines.

Eu raison des charges considérables que cette Société vonait de s’imposer par suite de l'achat des usines Daira Sanieh sur lequel nous aurons k revenir, la prudence devait lui reoom mander d'étudier aveo le plus grand sain les projets qu’elle avait en vue, de ne mettre h exéoution que les plus urgente et de faire en toute oocasion les plus strictes économies. Mais encore, de oe côté, o’eeî le contraire qui a lieu : des constructions nouvelles s'élè- vent de toutes parts, transformations hâtive», travaux inutiles, entreprises ooûteosee, que nous aurons k apprécier on détail dans notre troisième rapport Enfin, one augmentation chaque année du personnel fixe, la création de postes supérieure de plus en plus nombreux, augmentant encore les difficultés administra- tives par suite do la oonfasion des pouvoirs et des responsabilités.

De tous oes faite il ressort clairement qu'au lien de Chercher k faire des économies pour faite faœ aux charges nouvelles, les dépenses de toutes sortes étaient continuellement aug- mentées et que Messieurs les Administrateurs s’en rapportaient h la science financière de M Cronier poor combler les défi üte !
Cet transformations faites hâtivement et parfois si mal à propos devaient forcément amener le publiai « demander si da intiréti particuliers ne justifiaient pas les commande» de tous oes travaux.

Dans le but d'élucide'. la question, non> avons examiné les dépenses, faites -cour le* fournitures destinées atri usinas et ne»a avom constaté que toutes le* commande, i pari quelques rares exceptions, éfaiejt imitées psi Paris, nous avons môme découvert a ce suject une correspondance relative k des commamders que Paris contestait au Siège du Caire le droit de faire.

Cette correspondance que nous annexons a notre rapport sons les lettres D. B. P. voui unocture les distensions qui existaient dns le Conseil d’Administration de catte Société et, comme nous l'avons dit plus avant, la confu- sion des pouvoirs.
Les commandes poor lea uBines peuvent se diviser en trois catégorie* :
1. Installations nouvelle* et transformation rt d'appareils existants
2. Pièces do Rechange pour appareils exis- tanta. Pour ces 3 catégories il n’est pas dou- tenx que les commandes ne peuvent être faites qu'à des maisons spéciales pourvues de brevets, etc, etc.

Paris était mieux placé que le Caire pour traiter avec avantage et il n'eit pas possib'e d’émottra un avis sur lei prix payés tant que ces prix restent dans la limite raisinnable. La 3e catégorie comprend le- mat:èros de is consommation que l’on peut acheter comme le faisait la Daïra Panich au moyen d’adjud'oa- tions faites au Caire. Mais, encore pour celle»- là également, on peot estimer que la Rvfficerio Say, ayant chaque année des commàndes extrêmement importantes à faire poor elle- méme d'articles semblabV.il y avait nn crand intérêt pour la Soc-’é é lo don Suoreriea et de la Raffinerie à profiter des avan- toges qu'elle pouvait eu retirer en les faisant en commun ; et, si la oomparaisorf des prix unitaires payés par la Daïra Sanieh avec ceux facturés à la Société Générale des Suer, ries et de la Raffinerie d’Bgyp'e par Paris montrait que la Daîra Sinieh payait sos furnitures moins cher, on ne pourrait en déduire nn avis judicieux qu'à la condition de oomparor la qualité des produits, ce qui est actuellement impossible.

Ure vérification pratique ne pourrait être faite qu’à Paris même où sont passées les éori- tores originated do ces commandos, Pour la question des Report*, en exami- nant le bilan dressé au 81 octobre 1904, nous avons trouvé à l'actif le compte ' Cultures comptes communs” débiteur dn la sommn do Lst. 73,593, — et le compute Depenses pro- chaine campagne” pareillement débiteur de la somme do lat. 63,755.

Nous avons par cela été amenés à faire des recherches sur les dit* comptes et nous avons constaté qu’à l’preque do la clôture des comptes de l’exercice 1903 1904 on avait régulièrement porté au débit du compte "Exploitation géné rale" contre le crédit du compte, "Cultures da Lst 53,306,

-pour solder l’excédent dos dépenses cultu- rales campagne 1903 1904 (voir page 505 du journal), mais qu'ensuite cette somme avait eté reportée, comme déposées à amortir dans l'exercice suivant (voir page 539 du Journal), De même pour les comptes suivants : Exploitation Sucrerie Hawamdieb.”

"Exploitation Cheikh-Fadl et "Exploitation Nag Hamadi” on a fait un virement au débit du compte "cultures comptes communs” poor les sommes respectives do Lit 5.744, 7.737, 4,493 représentant des pins-values de qualité sur cultures de cannes,

En tout une somme de Lst 70,630, qui de oe fait figure i l'actif du l-ilan, taudis qu’elle ne représente que des pertes réol’cs subies effecti- Cement par l'exploitation culturale at qui, étant reportée pour être amortie dm* les exer- cioeà suivants, va fa'alcmont à la charge de l’exercice courant 1904-1905 qui vient de s’ar- ré ter brusquement au 31 août 1905. On a de la mê-ne manière reporté au débit du compte "Dépenses prochaine Campagne" une somme de Lst 34,717, ainsi répartie : Pour virement de partie do dépenses d'en- trotion et modifications do l'atelior do Minieh à répartir aux usines de l'Ibrahimieh Campagne 1904-1905 pour somme de Lit. 17,82b Pour Virement des dépenses d'entre.ien et frais généraux de t'usine de Rodah non mise en marche soit sur un exercice de 18 mois ; 9 mois à la charge do |a campagne 1904-1905 1 Lit. 5,683.
Pour virement commo ci derens, nrine d'Er- ment, lit 9,871.

Pour virement des dépenses de réfection et entretien des réseaux sud et nord, pour la mise en état des voies ferrées, pour la cam- pigne 1904-1905 Lit. 1.335. Soit au total Lst 38.717, qui vont avec les 1 précédentes Lst 70.630, figurer à l’actif de œ bilan 1903-1904 et qui ne sont cependant que des perte* réelles

Bu outre à côté de oea article* susmention- nés, il y en a un autre par lequel ou vire au crédit du Compte "Exploitation Générale” 1 l'exoédent d’une réserve faite en 1903-1903 et existant au crédit da Compte "Provisions pour litige en suspens" poir la somme de Lit 8.531. totalité de ces virements et de oes reports qui est de Lst 70.630 +34.717+ 3.531=Lst 108,860, nous a fait penser et nous croyons ne pas noua tromper qae ïon s'était servi de cet ]expédient pour oombler le déficit da Bilan pour 1 quel les Lst 313.717 d’arbitrages 1903 1904 useraient pas suffi, puisqu'il fallait faire figurer au débit du oompte dos Profit* et Perte* la double aemestrialité de Lst 109,300, payée à la Sugar Corporation.

Nons devons faire remarquer que ces reports pertes qui allaient figurer dans le Bilan à l'actif social dans la catégorie des oomptes dé- s biteure altéraient la situation véritable de la Société et montraient au public on aotif qoi réellement n'existait pas, puisque la tomme de reports n'était qu’une perte sèche subie dans l’exercioe et qui, devant être amortie dans les exercioea suivants allait être à la charge de coex-oi et absorber une partie de leurs bénéfices augmenter le montant do leurs pertes. Le Conseil d'administration /naturellement était amené à discuter et fixer ces report* qui autrement n'auraient pa être pesséi dans la comptabilité comme oeû a été fait, sans ordre lt formel de sa part

Ce qui ne s'explique pas, o’eat que les oen- rears n’aient dan* leur rapport rien déclaré à ce sujet et qu’il aient approuvé une situation qui n’était pas conforme à la réalité, A cette question de report* se rattaoh* oelle avsroes à la oultero, bien qu'ells soit e d’une nature différente parce que la réalisation Je cas anticipations dépend du résultat de campagne bukurale. Lee oetuteur*, MM. Bondi ot Bimseostain dani leurs lettres do 9 man 19( 2 et >5 man 1903'(toît annexe G.H.) waieat abordé oette question et demand lient J»ns la première son insertion »n,procè»-verbal Je la pin*prochaine réunion do Conseil. Ils priaient en outre le dit oonseil de Ienr fournir ^es documenta oompleta relatifs b oes svanoos pont se rendre compte de la «inoérité des ohiflres qni étaient présentés à justification Je oette partie si importante de l'actif. Noos n’avons pas trouvé tnoe de cette lettre dans les procès-verbaux du Conseird'ad ministration, mais nous avons oonsta'é q"Q via avanoei à la culture directe, tout au- jourd'hui excessivement réduites.

A IVx'men des oomptes Primes de rem- nuraouimii figurant 4 l'actif du bilan actuel, nus avons constaté que la réussite de la oon- raraiou des obligations 1902 et de la nouvelle i.nisvion 1905 est due principalement, 1. au ■ rédit dont la Société des Sucreries et de la t-iffinerie d'Egypte jouissait en raison des iividendea rémunérants qu’elle distribuait mouellemeut ; 2. 4 la protection quq, loi ijcordait le syndicat financier de Paria ; 8. an tom de Cronier qui s’imposait alors sor les narohés; 4 la Société Générale qni prêtait son ! icoonrs. Il y avait euoore les intéiêts privés lés agents dont les commissions étaient oon- lidérablcs. En effet la oonversion dea oblige- rons 1902 coûta 86 fr. 25 de commission par itre, ces obligations'tarent vendues 4 franos 186 25 par titre qni se réduisirent 4 fr. 449,85 i c»use des frais, sans tenir compte de l'amor- i «ernent des primes des obligations anciennes. .Pour les obligations nouvelles affectées spé- ialement an rachat des obligations de la i-igar Corporation, la 8ociété Généralo trouva l sa ooRvenar.ee d'en prendre ferme l’émission > francs 161,666 par titre et le prix ressortant m fsveor do la Société, dédootion faite des immissions, frais, fut de fr. 452,299. Les primes de remboursement qui figurent ,u bilan soit £207,544, pour la conversion les obligations en 1902 et £73,602, pour la lonvel'ff émisiion .oolwtitnont les différences n.tro le prix nominal et œlui de revient des itrea émis.
Jetons maintenant nn rapide oonp d'œil sur as tableaux relatif* anx exp'oitatiens générales le la Société et 4 ses pertes et profits réels [«puis le fbr novembre 1899 jarqn'an 81 août .905.

De coi tableaux, il résulte, qne même dans iss exorcisîs, jl y avait eu diminution dn spiral dns aux chargea sociales, anx frais ;énéraux d'administration et aox frais oom- unns des usines, et l’on se demande comment s Conseil d'administration apn cacher si long- emps anx actionnaires une situation si dé- wtreoso et se permettre de faire des dépenros i é'evéea jnsqn'4 payer des indemnités spé- ale et dea participations. exagérées an* dministrateors-délégnée et directeurs d'usine* irsque les-bilans, sans tenir oompte des arbi- rages, seo'Aturent par de* durits oonridé- Dans oe» tableaux, les'Arbitrages figurent n ronge dans une Alol pour dé- lontrer qne les Mnéfiîes portés an* b:lant mbliéiparje Conflrit'd'adminjstration n'étaient ne le montant de oes arbitrages augmenté* o diminués des béoéfioes on des pertes de exploitation.

Le 'tableau B des pertes et profita donne la itnation économique de la Société 4 la fin de haoan des exoroice» qne bons avons examinés ans tenir oompte des arbitrages qni c«pendant ont partie dn même tableau poor justifier, .vec la partie : “Application des Arbitrages" e qne nons avons déclaré dans notre préoédent apport, o’est kdire qne ceux-ci turvenaient au 1ernier moment dans la juste mesure qo’il allait ponr oombler le déficit causé par l’ex- >!oitation industrielle, laisser on reliquat et layer les dividendee aux actionnaires, au Con- leil d’administration et les antres intérêts itatu tairas.

Poor nous pronouoor sur la véracité des ipérationa d'arbitrage et qooiqoe nous ayons imstaté I'existenoe an siège dn Caire des ixtraita de comptes détaillés, il faudrait les ré ri fier dans loi livres comptables de la 8ociété J. Say et Cie en liquidation aveo les pièces iriginales des achats effectués poor le oompte le la Société Générale dea Sncrerios. “Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”

div.head: REVUE C0MMERCIALE
div.p: Cotona—Deux prétoxtos, poor Io m' drule*, ont servi die point de départ pou: mouvement à la hausse qui a commoucé à n corbeilio samedi dernier : le premier, lo bn lard que nous avions à Alexandrie ce matt et qui a inspiré une pourblene à une partit petit découvert, sur l'assertion infondée c s'étendait h touto la Bawo-Egypte, ot le sec l’annonce par un haussjer de New^fork i killing frost dans la Caroline du Nord.

Si 1er intéressés «’étaient donnés la peiui réfléchir,'ils auraient trouvé qu’un brouil do la mer ne pouvait pas aller bion loin c l’intérieur et que, dans tous les cas, en c saison, il n’y avait plus que la fraîcheur pût nuire aéx noix do h troisième ci létte, ot que, en oe qui concerne la américaine, elle ne concordait nullement i l'état do marobé de New-York, et n'éma que d'une seule source, sujette à cautii cause de toutes les informations donnéss pe même maison depuis biantô: doux mois qu Caroline do Nurd provoqué une forte demande do la part do la spéculation, soit poor couverture. soit poor , aller à 1 hausso, d'autant plus qu i beaucoup outsiden avaient commencé à parler de , l'existent» d’un syndicat à la haus-ô sur No- vembre, et la conséquence do tout cela a été que les prix ont monté jurqn’à 14 1/8 pour - Novembre, mais pour finir à 14.

Lundi, nous avons eu quelques il actuation» aus importance, ,mais lo soir, tant sur la faiblesse de l’Américain, que sons la pression des réalisations, il y a eu recul à 13 29/33, 1 cours qui a'est^naintenu le lendomaiu pendant toute la journée jusqu'à l'arrivée, à boure tardive, d'une dépêche de Liverpool disant quo Miss Qiles venait de l.aaoer son estimation de j la récolte à 10.300,000 balles 1 Comme lo matin ' on nous avoit câblé une autre estimation.restée sans effet,de 12,000,000 de balle», on né fit pas trop de cas do ce que disait Miss Qilos ot tout 1'offet do son rapport s'est limité à produire un pou de fermeté. Le jour suivant, oette amé lioration do l'état du marché s'e»t changée en hausse marquée et depuis lors, ot cela précisé ment hier matin, nous avons été à 14 7/16 . mais.àoeniveau, et malgré rencoutagementqno ; continuait à nous offrir la hausso de l'Améri- cain, les vendeurs so sont trouvés être pim, nombreux quo les acheteurs, ce qui nous a 1 graduellement fait rétrograder jusqu’à 14 5/32 dans l’après-midi d'anjourd'bai. A l'extrême : clôture, pourtant, nons avons eu uno reprise à 14 9/32, dernier oours affiché, reprise motivée par la Émusse soudaine et prononcée que les dernières dépêchos de Liverpool nons ont apportée, en ajoutant que le temps en Améri- que était défavorable et que le baromètre baissait.

Comme on le voit, nous n’avons pas toujours suivi l’Amérique de près, mais le résumé de la situation pour la semaine est : 5/1G de hausse chez nous, contre 16 points poor l'Américain K Liverpool, ce qui est tout un. Sous le rapport de l'activité, lo marché a été assez satisfaisant ; toutefois, comme tendance, on remarque de l'hésitation, ce qoi s'explique par l’isolement dans lequel so trouve la pétitc spéculation dont l’adversaire,oes jours derniers, a été le oopncerce qui a suffi -amment vendu de contrats, dit-on.

La demande pour le disponible a été bonne et régulière, et les transactions de la semaine se sont élevées à un joli total. La filature,qui t / no cesse d’être sur la réserve pour les faturs, est constamment sur le marché pour tout oeqni est prompt embarquement, et cette circbn» tance nous fait prévoir une autre gros» semaine d’exportation à ajouter à celle qui vient de finir.

Quant aux prix, lenra variations ont été offi- ciellement résumées ce matin comme soit : Hausse de 3/8 sur les Mjt Afifi et 1/8 sur les provenances Hantc-Egypte. Par contre, le Abaa-i et lea Joannovich restent pen de- mandés et sans changement si r lea coor L’enchère beleieve; u. des Domaines a en lier bièretdan» /ensemble elle a donné un tat on pf- pins MtiiUisant que les précé- dentes. D’ialleo**, cette '.bis, la dite Adinini tration char-e de tomber sor ont journée propix
Liverpool est tonjonra pen brillant pour no bottom. Les ventes de 1a semaine, quoique ni pa pin» fortes, sont restées antre 100 et 300
Balles par jour et poor ce qui est des prix. nuons trouvons le disponible invariable, tand qne les futurs, entraînés naturellement pi notre marché, gagnent 14/64.

Da dehors on nous câble qa’avec la baisa il y a eu plus d’achats de matière premiere et l'Amérique, prenant prétexte de cela, nous envoie dépêche sur dépêche pour nous dire qne les cultivateurs retiennent la marchand! si si la, recettes vont diminuer k partir d qu’il cette samaino, quo la demande est formidi s end. ble ot qtjo la hansso eat inévitable snrtoc si lo temps se gd'e. A cola Price répond qn los prix aotuols escomptent mémo nn KiUin 10 dr FrUit, car la saison oit avancéo et cen’o: Hard p^,’ i0 coton qui nous manquera pour oett dans campagne. Il a pont-être raison, mais lo pari de la hausse pent aussi profiter des circom tancesqui lui cont favorable pour manuevrer.
Graines de Coton : demande a été régu- liere pour le disponible, mais n’a rich eu de particulier ; dans tons les cas, elle a suffi pot maintenir les conta b 51 1/2 pour les M Afifi.

L'exportation est asset bonne comparative ment a l’année dernière a la même époque. mais nous surious besoin de mieux, car manque de spéculation sorl’article fait du mi et le Commerce, dans les conditions actueüe n’a pas de contre-partie asset forts. Hull a ete soutennee, mais dès que les con- trats outs faibli chez nous, elle n’a pas manque de réduire ses limites. Cours actuels £5.12/6 octobre et £5,11/3 novembre et les 3 mois Affaires modérées.
Les contrats ta avaient bien débuté, mais la semaine a finai sur la cote de P.T. 55 3/4. Rare ment semaine a été aussi peu active.

Feves: Tout ce qui s’est passé depuis asmedi dernierest l'achat de 500 on 1500 ard., nouse ne savons trop an juste, au prix de P.T. 150 pour le compte d’un découvert sur Octobre. Si tout leur succès doit se limiter a cet exploit, les haussiers n’ont pas de quoi être si fiers.

div.head: OUR PARIS LELTER.
div.p: (From Our Correspondent.)
Paris, October 14.

A sudden fall in the temperature—even Paris talks of weather—coincides with a hasty return to the Ville Lumiere which has donned an automnal aspect. The long line of ugly wooden shutters of dirty grey have made way to delicate lace curtains, which at night throw out brilliant light. The heavy entrance doom are 10 longer doted—animation reign* para- mount. Pari* open-air life, as understood in past yean, is no longer the fashion, the Parisian havbg pronounced home-life (English style) as being chic. No married man dares go to his club or cafe at 5 p.m., as he was wont to do in the past; he has to go home to “fifooloak," nolens, volens. There tea and crumpete await him. Many already openly admit that "fifo- clock” is not such a bad institution, aftor all ; others praise it and remembered it, with the resell that cafds experience a sharp falling-off in their sale of absinthe, vermouth, and other “tonics." Womankind finds no words suffi- ciently expressive to render thanks to one of the effect* of the "entente cordiale." Yet more ample evidence of the Frenchman's growing likeness for your national beverage — honi soit qui mal y ponse—drop in at Rumpel- mayer's, for instance, every table is occupied by the super cream of Parisian society drink- ing tea, discussing tea and dress—oven politic) and scandal are on the wane.

Tea is not confined to “indoor life:” see the hundred and one motor can outside; the chauffer are alto drinking tea. Is tea respon- sible for their reckless driving! If so, give at back our absinthe, keep your tea, for the alarming number if accidents caused by reck less chauffeurs it nothing lent than appalling So much to that hospitals are opening special wards for motor car victims, with special staffs. Police-stations are now expected to hav- several coffins at hand, as hospitals positively refuse to take in a body over which a 60 h. p car has left the imprint of its four wheels. “Hospitals take in injured persons,not mangled remains, not portions of bodies.’’ A Govern- ment Commission is sitting at present charged with the difficult million of solving the motor carriage puzzle, a complex question more diffi- cult to solve than most persons think. Mean- time, those not tearing about in care stay at homo am) drink tee. Even on Sunday it is not safe to attend church; many a smash-up occurs at the very door of the edifice. It is not rare to see five cars abreast speeding to the Madeleine, oath chaefferr deeming it a point of honor to get his party in first, with the result that in many instances would be church- goers are invited to follow the agents de villa to the nearest police-station.

Tha "Aurora" publishes a letter addressed to M. Clemenceau by Mr. Alfred Austin, it which the Poet-Laureate ram irks that at thi furthcoming Nelson centenary fites IhePrenct and British flags will float side by side, and adds :—' It is my most earnest desire, and i so sore that of the whole British people ip that in the commemorative letes of the 21st Prince will not see any lapse from that deli- cate esteem in which we hold the friendship so happily established between us. If the retreat of a nation could be measures by the num- Ber of its success on land and sea .-France could show a long series of victories unsur passed in the annals of any country. If. on the other hand, in the early years of the 19 century England and Prance mat si Enemies it was only because our ideas of liberty and the rights of nation were not those which appeared to animate the great but aggressive panics who then disposed of the resources of a too generous France. To day our ideas of liberty end the rights of Other nations coincide, so that benceforth, a at, present, nothing will prevert us from acting in unision in resisting all ur justifiable schemes of attack and aggrandiement, what ever their theatre and whoever their author maybe."

Paris railway stations are particularly animated these past few days, owing to the departure of "la classe." Accompanied to the French tute, corresponding to ‘ See the Cou- quering Hero Comes," thousands of young Parisians, drawn from every class of life, assemble at the various dejotes to be eutrained for their respective regiments—infantry, ca- valry, artillery. It is a great day in the life of each ; yesterday ho was a civilian, almost a schoolboy; to day he is a soldier, "under the Flag.” Perhaps for the first time in his lifts he leaves home and family, Paris. Ho will reach his destination to find bis barracks surrounded by snow many feet deep, or by an ooean of burning sand—the lucky ones remain in Prance, the unlucky ones are drafted to the colonies. Moat leave with at least a cheerful counten ance, some, indeed, hope to achieve .fame, glory. For two years be is free of material worry, he is clothed, fed, supplied with tobacco, and earns one halfpenny a day. Under the vigilant eye of the officers the raw recruits entrain with more or leu promptitude; one feels he mast kiss dear old mother, who has accompanied him to the station ; another must assure his sweetheart once more of his eternal fidelity, a third must tell his or ole that a money-order is always acceptable to the solder. As the trail moves out, heads poking out of every window send forth a lusty cheer of "Vive la France." Those left behind, with a mournful heart, yet proud to see their sons and brothers bound on what is regarded here as a sacred mission, respond with "Vive la Classe.” Universal service is not without its moments of pride for son and mother.

Shouts, deep imprecations, terrible oaths Hemmed in by infantrymen with fixed bayo- nets, another contingent of “la clasae" reaches the station. Behind them a rabble of evil-look- ing men and women attempting tc break the lines. Finding this impossible, they jeer at the soldiers, cheer the “classe.” This strange con- tingent is en route for Africa, whore they will be enlisted in the “Batt. d’Af,” or French African Disciplinary Regiments, where a disci- pline of iron is not one instant relaxed ; where an offence, a breach of discipline, means pu- nishment which would cause an inveterate gaolbird to shudder. The recruits for the “Batt. d’Af." are drawn from prison, are composed of those young men who previous to joining the flag at 2O have undergone a term of prison. The Paris “apaches” make of this corps one of the most dangerous to drill. The soldier of the "Batt. d’Af." is not recognised by the conscript; his uniform differs, he is drawn from the scum of the city. Nevertheless, it mast be said in all fairness that when they are called out to fight they fight like devils, capable of the great- est heroism, capable of the impossible, even of saving a wounded officer, whom, on any other occasion, they would readily murder. The Foreign L’gion should not be confounded with the “Batt. d’At"

Literary and artistic circles are earnestly engaged in the gruesome controversy to decide whether there really is such a thing as death beauty! Is there such a thing as death being beautiful to the eye t One section emphatically dec’ares that death-beauty really exists, and pity those persons who cannot fix it This party gravely refer the”unbeliever” to Chateaubriand. Lamar tin. Victor Hogo, and Piaubort Those great writers and poets do not hositate ono moment to paint the glorion* beanty of death and loveliress of the corpse. Per contra, the o’her section vehemently deny that there is each a thing as death beauty. They refer the "unbeliever” to sturdy the immortal pictures by Riberia and Q labaran. These pictures re- present dead bodies, and show, they assort, death as it is, vivid, terrible, if not ghastly Will this controversy cross the Channel to Meantime, the controversy waxes fierce. What do your authors, poets, and painters think I

"Wanted- Good Singers.” This will sur- prise some, pass unneeded by others. Never heless the fact remains, Paris needs good stage singers. The Operes, Opera Comique, whilo attracting full houses-foor-fifths Ame- ricans—are gradually being deserted bjr the Parisian, the lover of truly fine singing. Forms* "abounds” irreverently declare that they are tired of listening to old birds (sio demand a change. Easier .raid than done, notwithstand- ing radical changes being made at the Conser- vatoire, where “promising singers are taught bowling." The dearth of good singers is so crest that a committee of artists, comprising Meyer, Saint-Safas, Massenet, Ch. Dubois, Paladilbe, Lenepren, and Faure, are carefully examining the quuestion, and will endeavour to find good singers. Meantime, Paris theatres produce excellent soon cry, if little else. That M. Francis de Nion, the dramatic critic of the "Eoho-de Paris," should have protested against M. Antoine's refusal to invite him to the dress rehearsal at his theatre is a proof that he is a worker. For this week the dramatic critics have been the hardest- worked people in Paris, and to find that at least one theatre was closed to him must have been a lelietto M. de Nion when he first heard the news But then he remembered the dignity Of his profusion—dramatic criticism is the most dignified profession in the world except- ing that of the butler—and Aol us-like, shook up and scattered his winds. There is small chance of much result from the quarrel. M. Antoine considers that M. da Nion’s criticism damages his goods. "Give us good goods,” M. de Nion answers, and this M. Antoine has done in ‘ Vers l’Amour," which seems likely to hold the bill for many weeks to come, and which, I learn, Miss Marbury has sold already both to England and the United States.

beless, the fact remains, Pane needs good stage singere. The Opéra, Opéra Comique, while attracting fall houses— four-fifths Ame- ricans—are gradually being deserted by the Parisian, the lover of truly fine singing. Former "abonnés" irreverently declare that they are tired of listening to old birds (sio),and demand « change. Easier said than done, notwithstand- ing radical changes being made at the Conser- vatoire, where "promising singers are taught bowling." The dearth of good singers is so great that a committee of artists, comprising Meyer, Saint-Saens, Massenet, Ch. Dubois, Paladilhe, Lenepren, and Fanré, are carefully examining the question, and will endeavour to find good singers. Meantime, Paris theatres produce excellent scenery, if little else.

That M. Francis de Nion, the dramatic critio of the "Echo-de Paris," should have protested against M. Antoine's refusal to invite him to the dress rehearsal at his theatre I is a proof that he is a worker. For this week the dramatic critics have been the hardest- worked people in Paris, and to find that at least one theatre was closed to him must have been a relief, to M. de Nion when he first heard the news. But then he remembered the dignity of bis profession—dramatic criticism is the most dignified profession in the world except- ing that of the butler—and Æolus-like, shook up and scattered his winds. There is small chance of much result from the quarrel. M. Antoine consider* that M. ds Nions criticism damages his goods. "Give us good goods,” il. de Nion answers, and this M. Antoine has done in “Vera l'Amoar," which seems likely to hold the bill for many weeks to come, and which, I learn, Miss Marbury has sold already both to England and the United States.

The famous "trio”of the team yacht Cata- rina, which scandalmongers assert created a sensation at Cowes are home once more after a strange journey fresh in the mind of the reader. Gallay, who had absconded with over 700,000 francs, very lavish with his money so long as he was free, showed miserly instincts while lodged in Bahia gaol. He complains bitterly that a bottle of lotion to ease his mosquito-bitten face was charged him 50,000 reis, that a glass of pale ale cost him 1,500 reis, an absinthe 2,000 reis. Although a bank clerk he appears ignorant that 50,000 reis represents about £4 sterling. As for La Me- relli, the fair one spends her time humming a Spanish tune picked up at Bahia.

Paris is bewailing the gradual disappearance of the "blonde” in both sexes, and is carelessly and clumsily looking for the cause. Statisti- cians have drawn up a terrible indiotment against fashion, but although Mme Lamode proclaims herself capable of altering faces and figures, is it not too much to credit her with the power to diminish the birth-rate of fair haired babies! The excuse offered by a school- mas’er is more ingenious, if less reasonable. He has been comparing the merita of his pupils according to the colour of their hair, and he finds that dark-haired children are, as a rule, more gifted than light-haired. Those who know the “tricks of the trade"—the use of pigmenta to give the appearance of fever, of red ink and a handkerchief to counterfeit a bleeding nose, of a large "braudy-baH" in the cheek to parody too:hache—those who know of what "man in the making" is capable, when he wishes to escape the terrors of school, will believe that he is not above changing the colour of his hair to divert the prejudice of his master. But we have first to be convinced that there is really more than one school master in France who accepts this theory.

div.head: THE CANALS IN MARS.
div.p: Ever since the presence of canals or channels (canali) on the surface of the planet Mars was first described by the Italian astronomer, C.V. Schiaparelli, in 1877, the question of their character and even of their real existence has, as a writer in the “Times" points out, been keenly debated. On the one hand they have been accepted as truly material formations. On the other some competant observers have failed to detect the canals at all, while others who have succeeded in seeing them have not agreed with each other in their descriptions of what they saw.

Within the last few months (continoes the it 'Times" correspondent) fresh light has been ' » thrown on the question by a piece of work car- ried out at the Lowell Observatory at Flagstsff, Arizona. The observers there have always been y among the most successful in seeing and draw- ing the canals ;and they resolved to supple- ment their visual observations by an attempt to photograph them in the favorable condi- tions presented by the planet's opposition in the spring of this year when it was com- paratively near the earth. Elaborate precautions were taken. The result was that Mr. Lampland, Professor Lowell’s assistant at Flagstaff, suc- ceeded in obtaining in May and June a num- - ber of photographs of the planet at different stages of rotation, which show canals quite distinctly, and even present indications of the , doubling ' which has been regarded as still ; more doubtful than the existence of the canals ; themselves. The defining power of the eye, however, is so much superior to that of the photographic plate that, although some 400 canals and 175 oases have been made out by Professor Lowell himself, the photographs have , so far revealed only about 40 canals and four or five oases. The conclusion would seem to be that the canals, whatever be their nature and origin, cannot be mere subjective illusions on the part of certain observers, but have an actual existence as material formations on the surface of Mars.

div.head: THE BELLS OF BOW.
div.p: At noon on Wednesday, last week, the throng of Cheapside heard again the chimes of Bow, which hare been stilled since 1823, in the refrain which called Whittington back from his seat at the foot of Highgate HilL. The recent re-hanging of the twelve bells in the belfry of Bow Church gave to the rector, the Rev. A. W. Hutton the opportunity he needed to re-establish the old chimes which had been familiar to Londoners for so many centuries. Sir Villiers Stanford has composed the setting for the words, to be rung at all hours and quarters in the following order :— First quarter, Torn again !
Second quarter, torn again, Whittington ! Third quarter, Torn again, Whittington, torn again !
Hoar, Torn again, Whittington, thrice Lord Mayor of London!

Shortly before noon a few parishioners and others of the neighborhood met in the vestry of the church, where the Rev. A. W. Hatton briefly explained the restoration of the chimes. The tune, he said, had once been familiar, but it had not been played on Bow bells since the Great Fire. He himself disparaged the legend of Whittington having heard the chimes at High- gate, but perhaps be had heard the curfew tolled on the great bell.

div.head: THE ALIENS ACT.
div.p: It is officially announced that the Home Secretary has appointed the following gentle- men to be a committee to consider and report what rules and orders ought to he made to give effect to the provisions of tho Aliens Act, and to rocommend the arrangements which may in their opinion be necessary for bringing the Act into operation at the various ports in the United Kingdom: Mr. Mackenzie Dalzell Chalmers, C.B., C.8.I., ” Permarent Undersecretary of State for the H Home Department (Chairman) ; Mr. Robert Henderson, C.B., Secretary to the Board of Customs ; Mr. J. W. Cawston, of the Treasury ; Mr. R. C. Heron-Maxwell, of the Board of Trade ; and Mr. John Pedder, of the Home Office. Mr. W. Haldane Porter has been appointed secretary to the committee.

div.head: RECOGNITION OF GENERAL BOOTH
div.p: The London papers announce that the freedom of the City of London will be pre- sented to General Booth at the Guildball ® on Thursday, the 26th inst., when the Lord Mayor will preside at the ceremony, and Sir Joseph Dinsdale, M.P., as Chamberlain, will make the presentation. The "General" will also be presented on a later occasion with the freedom of the City of Nottingham, General Booth is not unknown to Egypt, and it will be remembered that he paid a visit to Port Said lat season, and delivered a most stirring address at the Soldiers’ Home, in which be related many of the trials which he has gone through and told how be had emerged from them successfully.
